Early Access Review

Update - 3/9/15
I didn't make it past loading into a new dungeon.
3 mobs came at me when I opened the first door.
I had a message that I did not have the reagents to use my spells.
The mobs couldn't kill me though, so I just stood there while they tried to kill me since I couldn't fight back.
I couldn't even make it back to the main menu, I only had the option to 'quit' which exited the game.
All of these other reviews seem pretty far away from what I played.  You could only 'play' this game for 40 hours if you left it idle in the background to log those hours for a 'review'.  People can hide under the guise of 'Early Access', but there just isn't a core system or mechanics to build off of here.

Then outside of the game lacking any general direction, there is just too much baggage attached to the developer.  I had no clue all of this was going to go down when I stupidly bought this game and made my first review.  It would take a heck of a lot of work for them to dig themselves out of this persona they built for themselves, but who wants to stick around for it when there is so much else going on in the gaming world.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------

***I'll update my review after some basic patches are deployed.  I don't have time to moderate a review everytime someone posts a link to your past, and I can't update my review if you lock it due to links.  Just take a deep breath and work on your game.***


Initial Review:
I went in blind, and came out a sucker.  I'm all about a jenky indie game that could use some help, but this is one isn't even ready for an early access release.  Overpriced is an understatement.

My first 5 minutes of game play:
The dragon on the opening screen is facing away from you and his wings clip through the title... amazing.
The UI is ready to melt your eyeballs.  They picked all the wrong colors and crammed text into all of the wrong places.
Loads of loot to open but absolutely no indication of why I would care to do it.
Lots of static models are floating and not touching the floor.
Enemies can just walk through walls, stairs and doors.  I had them clip into the stairs and kill me, couldn't fire back.  This isn't like a one-off thing either, this happens all the time.
The UI strikes again.  Clicking on anything in the UI will cause you to fire.
Absolutely 0 introduction to the mechanics or idea of the game.  Where is my mana and how do I replenish it?  Why do I want gold? Why are there a billion things to loot and what do they do?
I leveled a skill up!  What do I need to do about that and where?
So basically there is just a lot of confusion and zero excitement.  I can play through a buggy game, but there is just this general lack of vision and core gameplay at the moment.  I wasn't hip to the developer’s history before I jumped in, so I guess I was asking for it.  I might load it up again if the UI gets any sort of love, enemies don't walk through walls and some basic gameplay tool tips are added.


0/10 - Feels like an unfinished cash grab.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I know this is early access, but the game has some serious issues from the get-go. There is no menu (that i can find) in game to remap controls, no tutorial, no explaination of keys. This is a seriously lackluster way to bring fans into the game, especially something as unforgiving as a rogue-like. If you want to know what to do, you need to go through the control mapping part of the settings window that comes up at launch of the game.
Not a game-killing issue, there is a lot of promise, but then comes the uglyness of the actual gameplay.

Very little information about what is lootable and what isn't. No explaination of how crafting is done, or where to get crafting items. Some large groups of enemies spawn on Level 1 and make it almost impossible to kill them, without being absolutely wrecked the second you start to shoot at them. On top of  this, enemies are not at all staggared towards the player in the beginning. Storyline or Random Dungeon, both will spawn large amounts of stuff at you and prevent you from getting very far until you put a lot of practice into the level. This is definitely a game that needs some improvement and so far, i'm hoping that the developers will work hard enough to bring us to that point!

There is a lot of possibilities for this game, especially if players work together with the devs in getting content towards patches and stuff :)
Until then though, there is a lot of work needed to make this game better, and hopefully it will come soon. Until that happens, if you're looking to play something like this, wait. The possibilities of this being a great game are there! I'm waiting with baited breath for some more issues to be finalized. I will revisit this review once that happens :)

It's just not any good.

I must admit, the models are well made. Props to the guys/gals who made them (I forget the name, but something with P on the Unity Asset Store). And it's kinda nice to see a First-Person-Mage game again. But that's all for the good side of this game.

Honestly, every other part is lacking much or plain bad.

The dungeon layouts are boring and repeat themselves, you always know where and how many monsters will appear. And it's just on one level, no going up or down. Always the same looking hallways with the same boring rooms with some set number of monsters. That's not good level design. No incentive to explore, well, no possibility to explore anything.

There is also no challenge whatsoever. Just equip the most recent offense spell and spam it till all the baddies are dead. (Nice animations though, props to the guys/gals, you know...) Most enemies just take one hit and you can fire your spells as soon as the last projectile hit. In the boss fights you can stun the bigger ones and spam your spells - easy win.

Crafting is there, but I honestly don't know if it does anything. Yea, some random number go up and it has probably some influence on how you perform but I couldnt care less. Items are boring and standard and there is not much variety at all, just +22 here or +24 there. No unique stuff, no nothing. Same for the offensive spells, which are just different colored rockets. Hell, you could even swap out the spells for candies and it wouldn't matter one bit.

Defense spells are a little more varied but then there are traps, stuns and summons. Summoned creatures wont have any intelligence and tend to get stuck in walls. But then that fits with the monster AI which is pretty much non-existent. No need for tactics, they'll run into their doom nontheless.

And that's it. That's  the game. Gameplay won't change past the first level, monster assets seem to swap bexond level 5 but then it doesnt really matter. Environments stay the same. Menus look cheap, too.

Bugs: Yea, there are some of them. You can lose your ability to cast spells which renders you dead. Items randomly disappear and reappear and you cant do anything about it. I didnt run into any crashes so thats good.

The GUI has some kind of odd behaviour and tends to open to many windows at once which you have to close one after another. You also can't loot all the stuff in a dead body at once so there's unnecessary clicking. Spells have weird descriptions and say something about ingredients which don't exist at all. So, are the descriptions just copied from somewhere else? I don't know and I don't care.

I bought this game for 1 buck and I can't recommend it even for that price. It's just bad. There are lots of games which work waaaaaay better than Deadly Profits and which don't rely on bought Unity assets. (To be clear: This isn't the issue here, it could have been a good game with bought assets, but it isn't.) If you're looking for a first-person dungeon crawler shooter hybrid, stick to Ziggurat or if you don't mind the setting try games like Fancy Skulls, Tower of Guns or even Paranautical Activity. Or play Legend of Grimrock. Yea, you should probably play that.

reviewText:
Haven't played very long on this game, and don't think I ever will.  I had it on my wish list from a while ago, and saw it on sale for a dollar, so figured I'd give it a buy.  Guess I should have double checked it, despite being on my wish list.  Least I only lost a dollar.

The game has an interesting concept, an FPS in the style of Doom, but with Roguelike elements.  It fails on delivery though.  Enemies are all basically the same, they just look different.  Perhaps later on they manifest some different traits, but right now they just rush you and die instantly.  The interface is kind of clunky, particularly looting monsters.  Game doesn't pause while you loot, and there is no loot all button, and if you should close the loot without grabbing something, it's gone.  This gives it a very alpha/beta feel.  I know it is just recently out of that stage, but it seems like they did it prematurely.

Stats don't seem to do anything, or at least nothing about them is mentioned, other than int increasing your damage.

The graphics aren't great, but I wasn't expecting that, and they aren't terrible either.  The problem is the sound.  Seems like everything in the dungeon makes noise no matter how close you are.  It's a bit creepy at first to hear all kinds of chittering bugs and such, but eventually it just grows annoying as you can't even remotely rely on sound to locate enemies or warn of them sneaking up on you.  This once again gives it a very unpolished feel.

Can't be too mad about the deficencies for a dollar, but all in all I suggest giving the game a pass unless/until the game gets a few more major overhalls.

reviewText:
There's many things wrong with this game, but the most noticeble at the start is its lack of feedback. The opening screen is a CG dragon moving around in an automated pattern behind poorly rendered fire particle effects. To the right were buttons (Start Game, Delete Character, Quit Game), that had no feedback when pressed. Pressing Start Game merely took me to the next screen without any indicated that I had pressed it. The same happened in the next screen. There were several things to press, but all of them just brought up a menu and paused all of the moving animations in the background.

When actually playing the game for the first time, I was looking around and getting used to the controls, and I got killed by a monster without even knowing. I was immediately booted out of the dungeon and placed back in the main menu. I tried again and kept my eye out for monsters. I used my mouse button to shoot monsters and killed them all with one attack. All of the monsters take only one attack to die except for the Ogres that take several. The amount of attacks it takes to kill the Ogre is egregious compared to how few it takes to kill the rest. After enemies die, their bodies stay in the dungeon and the player can walk through them. The controls section says that I should be able to loot the monsters using the ‘F’ key, but I could not at all.

After fighting some monsters, you level up and get a new spell. However, you can only have access to getting this spell in the main menu. It was very hard to find, but if you click on the wizard to the right, a window pops up with a tab where the player can change their spells. Even though the player does not really need to switch spells because they will all kill the monsters in one hit.

When leveling up the player, there are no stat increases. There is just text that pops up on the screen. The player receives a new spell, and at certain levels players can go to different dungeons, but that is it.

reviewText:
Deadly Profits is a game with an accurate name:
If you buy it cheap enough (sales) and sell the cards you'll actually make profits.
But playing it is really detrimental if not deadly (for your sanity), let me explain why.


*It is not far from ugly
*It is badly optimized and will take a lot of computer power to render a corridor and a few enemies
*Consequently to the previous point, it is laggy and stutters quite a lot
*It's boring. No really. It's so easy that you can beat dungeons that are above your level witout taking a single hit.
*You one shot all enemies once you've a decent spell levelled. Find your favourite spells and never switch again.
*The boss aren't a challenge as tehy are dumb as rocks. They're so big they get stuck in the level geometry, thus becoming easy targets
*This games takes two hours at large to set up a game breaking exploit that will allow you to get endgame gear realy quickly and to become overpowered

You think it's over?
Think again.

* The sound design will make you mute the game because of the enemies' sounds that are just annoying and badly 3D rendered (the sound will reflect the postion of the enemy accurately enough but not the distance they're from you)
* The interface is just hideous
* The gear and items icons look like they were stolen from a child version of D&D
* The whole lighting settings make the game look like it's been oiled. Everything reflects light like oil have been poured on it.
* The animations and interface are not paced with the game's logic. Example: the interface will take up to two seconds to update after you took a hit or something
* It takes more time to drop the Steam Trading cards than it takes to be tired of the game
* Some spells look like they were made in ten minutes with basic Unity Engine functions (ex: a sphere that travels forward following the cursor, and stops upon hitting an enemy, freezing the enemy's animation and movement)
* Spells you cast FOLLOW your CURSOR. Means that if you throw a spell at some enemy and target another enemy, the spell will follow and hit the second enemy, not the first one.

There are some positive sides however:
* Made profit selling the trading cards
* It can be played if you're extremely bored and desesperate
* ♥♥♥♥ it was only $0.19
* Sold the cards for $0.24
* Makes a good horror story to tell at night around a campfire with fellow gamers

20/100

I don't think this is a horrible game, it's just not refined and it's certainly quite buggy. I wouldn't recommend it, though I don't think it's as bad as many reviews say it is.

I played some random missions before working out that there was a campaign. I (barely) won my first random mission and then couldn't figure out how to get back, so I quit. Luckily my progress was saved. Second random mission was easier, as I worked out how to use the crafting system. Pretty cool, and it's fairly obvious once you stare at it enough. Click an option, check the bottom and see if you have all the components. That mission ended as soon as I killed the boss. Hmm. Third mission, which was actually my first campaign mission, I realised that a portal appears once you kill the boss and you just walk through it. Aha.

After finishing the first mission of the campaign, I went back to the campaign, and the first mission was the only one that was available. Huh.

Oh yes, jump is bugged. Most of the time, the screen just kinda stutters. It even did that when I was in the large boss room. It did work once though. Weird bug.

TL;DR: While not terrible, I wouldn't recommend the game too much. It's nice that it's cheap, but it's likely to frustrate people more than entertain them. I think the devs could spend a few hours tidying it up and it would be a MUCH better game.

reviewText:
I'd have to say that so far this is maybe the best Digital Homicide game I've played...Not that it's good but at least they didn't ♥♥♥♥ it up too badly.
It's a simple game: you're a mage (no other character options), going into dungeons, killing monsters (there are like 10 kinds of monsters or so) to: 1 level up your character and 2 get loot that will be used either to sell and buy equipment or to craft items. There's not a story here: you teleport into the dungeon, you kill everything that moves, you teleport back to the shop.
The looting can be a problem: often you need to move around a dead body until you get the right angle and when you close the looting window the cursor will sometimes be stuck, and since the cursor is the only way to rotate your character and to aim that means you need to reopen the inventory and close until it fixes.
Also in 2 out of 4 dungeons I went into, when I got out my inventory was nearly empty, and I had just picked quite a few items.
Other inventory bugs seem to be comon: my character is wearing a pair of gloves on the helmet slot for a while now...the gloves just decided to stay there instead of the hands and a couple of times when I oppened my inventory, my character was totally naked and it should have like 4 or 5 items on.
Also you pick up gold on the dungeons that you can use to buy equipment but there is no way to know how much gold you've got. You can try to buy an item and if you got enough gold you will get it or if you don't it will just say you haven't got enough money.
Also there are two modes: Random dungeons where you choose to get an easy (1 lvl below your charater), normal (same lvl as the character) or hard (1 lvl above) dungeon, and that kinda works (even if the dungeons look all the same with the same enemies just slightly weaker); and the campaign mode where you should folow an order of dungeons with increasing lvl, which I managed to finish the first dungeon twice and can't get to any other, it just says I need to do the first one and won't let me go to the second.
The game says you should head back to town if your health is low but even when I tried my health never went bellow half the total.
Also the dungeons are a low graphic stone textured series of corridors in brown with golden details while most of the enemies are brown with gold and black details. As I said they all look the same, all just like this.

So this is an extra easy, ugly, boring and glitchy game.

Edit: and even if the esc menu has the option to turn off the music, it stays on unless you turn of the sound. The sounds should help you know where the enemies are but since you keep on hearing spiders and other monsters from way too far, there's not really much point. You still have no idea how far they are.

There is no story provided. You don't know why you're there or what it is you're trying to accomplish. While there is a Campaign Mode, it doesn't do anything to resolve the lack of information. What you quickly discover is that you are to enter a multitude of dungeons, kill anything that moves, collect random loot drops, and proceed to a boss encounter. In the past 5 years - that is, since I first got The Digital Homicide Collection - I have started many playthroughs of Deadly Profits. And I have always given up during the first few dungeon sections. I thought it was nothing more than a boring dungeon crawler and I just couldn't keep myself interested at all. But now, almost 11 minutes after its initial release, I suddenly decided that it's the right time to give it another chance.

And after finishing it I don't regret a single minute.

It's true, let's face it. The game only truly starts after you get away from that mage shop, and then... Pure awesomeness commences. It's so fantastically designed that the magic fights never feel boring, there's one action after another, every single location is filled with its own unique atmosphere and while the story isn't the most creative or breathtaking one, the game more than makes up for it with everything else. It feels so great to play, and you've gotta play it yourself to really understand.

Applause to Digital Homicide and a slap in my face for not playing this masterpiece earlier. One of the best video games ever made.

reviewText:
A competent and well-made indie game that combines elements from the RPG, FPS, and Adventure genre. It includes an in-depth campaign complete with an interesting variety of spells, traps, summons, and enemies. The titular premise is simple; venture through a dungeon and defeat wave after wave of creatures. Pick up the loot and sell them to a vendor named Archimedes to obtain an armory of mythical proportions. While overall it is a decent game, it could have been improved upon immensely - refer to my critique below. Still, as an indie game, it needs to be evaluated under a different standard compared to that of evaluating games made by typical big name publishers.

The Good
+ Captivating graphics; I especially like the enemy models
+ Tons of spells to gain and items to craft
+ Includes a campaign
+ Alluring music that encapsulates a fantastical experience

The Bad
- The sound effects could have been better
- Needs a more complex storyline
- Most bosses and enemies go down quickly

I find the game to be very fun. Simplistic, but fun. there are a few things that need working on.

1. The controls need some work. I find myself being able to walk fine one minute then it's like I'm walking through glue for no reason. The mouse is way too sensitive even though I have it turned almost all the way down and my mouse's settings seem to have no effect, either.

2. The game should have environmental loot and the ability to break vases(with a possibility of loot in them). There's so much laying around in the dungeons, but why? You can't collect any of it. That's part of the fun of dungeon delving is looting the dungeons and the beasties.

3. Possibilty of being able to use the weapons you actually craft. I understand this seems to be a spell casting, dungeon delving game, but you're crafting weapons but not really using them. Maybe instead of weapons, you craft books or relics to carry along with you.

Over all, I find this a fun game. The graphics are great, over all the game play is fun and I can see myself playing this for some time to come. Short dungeons help make it not something I feel like I have to stick with for a while if I only have 15 or 20 minutes to play, but the campaign helps you feel it's a long lasting game.
